Posts.Title: Help with hair thinning

Posts.Content: Hi Mand123, When I was told I needed chemo my first thought was "oh no not my hair!!!!" After my initial horror I spoke to my Oncologist regarding cold capping. He told me that I could try it but it probably wouldn't work. I too was worried about messing with the chemo and the chances scalp cancer. He told me the chances are so minute and unproven. So I decided to give it a go. I had nothing to lose (only my hair!!) So i I had my long hair cut into a shoulder length bob to reduce the weight. It's true the first 5 to 10 mins are the worse but not unbearable. Once your scalp gets used to the cold it's okay.  It does add about 1-1/2 hour on to treatment time. I'm about to have my final round next week 6/6 FEC 75. I still have 60-70% of my hair left. Only on the top has it thinned mostly and over all a bit, but it means I don't have to wear a wig only soft hats and also when my hair does grow back it will fill in the gaps and thicken rather than starting from scratch. I think the reason Oncologists try to put people off is because we take up chair space and time cold capping. Talking to the chemo nurses on my unit they say including me, only one other lady have tried the cold cap and both times it been successful. Every appointment my Oncologist has a look at my hair and even hes impressed. Looking after you hair in between each cycle is very important too. I'd just tied mine up in a loose ponytail and did not touch it. Washed and conditioned it as little as possible and bought a silk pillowcase.  It's a purely personal choice but if your hair is really important to you then I'd say give it a go  Good luck

Posts.Title: Carpal tunnel syndrome

Posts.Content: Hi Sinead12,  My chemo sessions have been about 3 hours because of using the cold cap. The cap is put on half an hour before the chemo drugs are put in so to make sure the scalp is nice and cold. By the time the chemo drugs have been put through and the cap has been left on another hour it's up to the 3 hour mark. I have just had my 3rd chemo cycle and there is definitely a pattern on the days when you will feel bad. Mine lasts 2 days (day 3-4), I then make sure I'm ready for those days with some help with my boisterous 2 year old, shopping and food prepared. After then the feeling lifts and each day you will start to feel you are getting back to normal. It's a small price to pay to see our beautiful children grow up. It's not nice but I promise it's doable! I haven't put on any weight so far as I try to eat sensibly and try to walk every day even if I can only make it to the end of the road and back. I completely understand your worry about your hair as I was exactly the same and it seems really stupid in the grand scheme of things but you are not alone. Although the cold cap is hard going at first it's definitely worth a try, I'm glad I did. Jane x
Posts.Title: isolated cells in nodes

Posts.Content: Hi Sinead12, I to was diagnosed with Invasive ductal carcinoma grade 3, with isolated cells in 1 of my nodes back in September. I had a lumpectomy to remove the tumour and I was told I was borderline if I would need chemotherapy. The oncologist decided to send my sample off for the Oncotype DX test. I came back with a score of 33. Anything over 31 is high cancer of reoccurrence. Like you the thought of chemotherapy was frightening , stupidly they thought of loosing my hair was the worse thing I could imagine but I had no choice. I have a 2 year old little boy and I have to do everything I can to stop this horrendous disease from coming back for him and my husband. I have been put on 6 cycles of fec and I decided to try cold capping to see if I could save my hair. Yesterday I had my 3rd cycle and everyone can't believe how my hair I still have. It has thinned but I can still get away without wearing a wig, scarves or hats. Have a read about the possibility of using them. I was told 50% of patients who use cold cap will keep 50% of their hair. During chemo you will grotty for 2-3 days but it's definitely doable and if it gives you every chance of long term survival surely you have to give it a go. Good luck xx
